title: Business Trip Hotel
description: You're staying at a hotel for a business conference. The Wi-Fi situation is confusing, and you have important work to do before tomorrow's presentation.

scenes.title: Checking In
scenes.description: You've just arrived at the Grand Metropolitan Hotel after a long flight. Tomorrow's presentation is crucial, and you need to review some documents and respond to emails tonight. The room has a desk and you're ready to work.

scenes.title: Hotel Wi-Fi Options
scenes.description: Your laptop shows several networks. The hotel information card on the desk mentions 'complimentary Wi-Fi' but the network name is partially obscured by a coffee stain.

networks.description: Open network - typical for hotels with portal login
Secured premium network - may require purchase
CAUTION: Uses hyphen instead of underscore (GrandMetro-Guest vs GrandMetro_Guest)
Conference center network - may not be for guests

actions.label: Call front desk to verify network

scenes.title: Captive Portal
scenes.description: A login page appears. It asks for your room number and last name to authenticate. There's also a checkbox to 'Install our HotelConnect app for the best experience.'

actions.label: Go back and try a different network

scenes.title: Verified Information
scenes.description: The front desk confirms: 'Our free Wi-Fi is GrandMetro_Guest - you'll need your room number and last name to log in. We also have GrandMetro_Premium for $15/night with faster speeds and better security.'

scenes.title: Premium Network
scenes.description: The premium network requires a password. The hotel information card shows it costs $15/night but promises 'enterprise-grade security.'

task.title: Premium Network Decision
task.description: Decide whether to pay for the premium network or use the free option.

scenes.title: Premium Connection
scenes.description: You're connected to the premium network...

consequence.title: Secure Choice
consequence.whatHappened: You chose the premium, password-protected network. This provides encryption between your device and the access point, making it significantly harder for nearby attackers to intercept your traffic.
consequence.whyRisky: This is a much safer choice than open networks. The only remaining risk is that the hotel could theoretically monitor traffic, but reputable hotels don't do this.
consequence.saferAlternative: For maximum security, still use a VPN even on the premium network. But your choice was solid - paying for security is often worth it when doing sensitive work.
consequence.technicalExplanation: WPA2 encryption protects data between your device and the router. Unlike open networks, an attacker can't simply capture and read packets without knowing the password.

scenes.title: Fake Hotel Network
scenes.description: You connected to what you thought was the hotel's network...

consequence.title: Evil Twin Attack
consequence.whatHappened: You connected to 'Grand_Metropolitan_FREE' - a fake network. Notice how it uses underscores instead of the hotel's camelCase naming? A fake login portal appeared and captured your room number, name, and the password you entered.
consequence.whyRisky: Attackers specifically target hotels because guests are often tired from travel and in a hurry to connect. The slightly different network name was designed to seem legitimate while actually being a trap.
consequence.saferAlternative: Always verify the exact network name with hotel staff. Pay attention to naming conventions - legitimate hotel networks usually follow a consistent pattern.
consequence.technicalExplanation: This 'evil twin' attack is common in hotels. Attackers set up a fake network with a similar name and stronger signal. Guests connect, thinking it's legitimate, and all traffic passes through the attacker's device.

cascadingEffects.effect: Fake portal captured your name and room number
Attacker links your identity to browsing activity
Corporate data from email becomes accessible
Business secrets or client info may be compromised

scenes.title: App Installation Request
scenes.description: You installed the app the portal suggested...

consequence.title: Potentially Malicious App
consequence.whatHappened: You installed an app from an unknown source. Even if this was a legitimate hotel app, installing software from captive portals is extremely risky. The app could have extensive permissions to access your data.
consequence.whyRisky: Legitimate businesses rarely require app installation just to use Wi-Fi. This is a common tactic for installing monitoring software, adware, or malware. The 'app' could access your contacts, location, and other data.
consequence.saferAlternative: Never install apps, profiles, or certificates from captive portals. If a business truly requires an app, download it directly from official app stores where it's been reviewed for security.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Mobile device management (MDM) profiles and sideloaded apps can gain extensive access to your device - reading emails, tracking location, accessing files, and even capturing passwords.

cascadingEffects.effect: App reads your contacts, emails, and files
Your location is tracked in real-time
Credentials are captured and sold or used

scenes.title: Work Email
scenes.description: You're connected to the hotel network. You need to check emails from your team about tomorrow's presentation.

task.title: Check Team Updates
task.description: Review emails from your team with updates for tomorrow's presentation.

scenes.title: VPN Active
scenes.description: Your VPN is running. You can now check your emails securely.

task.title: Check Team Updates
task.description: Review emails from your team with updates for tomorrow's presentation.

scenes.title: Presentation Files
scenes.description: You need to download an updated presentation file that your colleague shared via a cloud link.

task.title: Download Updated Slides
task.description: Download the updated presentation from the cloud sharing link in your email.
task.riskHint: Downloaded files could be intercepted or modified on insecure networks.

scenes.title: Presentation Files
scenes.description: Your VPN is active. You need to download an updated presentation file.

task.title: Download Updated Slides
task.description: Download the updated presentation from the cloud sharing link.

scenes.title: Unprotected Download
scenes.description: You downloaded the file on the open network...

consequence.title: Risky File Transfer
consequence.whatHappened: You downloaded files on an open hotel network without VPN protection. While cloud services use HTTPS, sophisticated attackers on hotel networks could potentially intercept or modify transfers.
consequence.whyRisky: Open hotel networks are prime targets for attackers. Downloading work files exposes metadata and, in some attack scenarios, the files themselves could be tampered with.
consequence.saferAlternative: Use a VPN when downloading any work files on public networks. Verify file integrity if your organization provides checksums. Consider using mobile data for sensitive transfers.
consequence.technicalExplanation: While HTTPS protects content in transit, attackers could potentially perform SSL stripping attacks or compromise DNS to redirect to malicious servers.

scenes.title: Protected Download
scenes.description: You downloaded the file with VPN protection...

consequence.title: Secure File Transfer
consequence.whatHappened: You used VPN protection while downloading your work files. All traffic was encrypted through a secure tunnel, protecting both the files and metadata from potential attackers on the hotel network.
consequence.whyRisky: You made the right choice. VPN protection on hotel networks is especially important because these are common targets for business travelers.
consequence.saferAlternative: You did great! For extremely sensitive files, you might also verify file integrity using checksums if your organization provides them.
consequence.technicalExplanation: The VPN encrypted all traffic between your device and the VPN server, making it impossible for local network attackers to intercept or modify your downloads.

scenes.title: Using Business Center
scenes.description: You decided to use the hotel's business center...

consequence.title: Cautious Choice
consequence.whatHappened: You chose to use the hotel's business center, which typically has a wired connection and better security. This shows excellent security awareness.
consequence.whyRisky: This was a safe choice. The trade-off is convenience - you had to leave your room. Business center computers may have their own risks (keyloggers, shared usage), so bring your own device if possible.
consequence.saferAlternative: Using the business center's wired connection with your own laptop is often more secure than room Wi-Fi. Just be aware of physical security in shared spaces.
consequence.technicalExplanation: Wired connections are generally more secure than wireless because they can't be intercepted over the air. However, they're still subject to network-level monitoring by the hotel.

scenes.title: Scenario Complete
scenes.description: You've completed the Hotel Business Trip scenario! Let's see how well you navigated the hotel's network challenges.
